text.p: A cholera outbreak in the West African state of Guinea-Bissau has killed 15 people and 182 new cases have been reported in the last three days, the Portuguese news agency Lusa said on Tuesday.
Lusa quoted health ministry figures as showing that most of the 475 cases reported so far were in the capital Bissau.
Health authorities declared a cholera epidemic in the former Portuguese colony on October 11.
The previous cholera epidemic in Guinea-Bissau, which lasted from October 1994 to March 1995, killed 290 people.

Cholera, spread by poor hygiene or contamination of drinking water by sewage, brings on severe diarrhoea and dehydration and kills if not treated quickly. Outbreaks often coincide with the rainy season in West Africa.
The disease is relatively easy to treat but health workers say rehydration fluids and medicines are in short supply.
